name: Brooch: untitled (compass rose II)  (2013)
description:
Materials: Optometrist's test lens, fused glass, resin, 19th-century steel-point engraving, 18th-century paper.


A tie-tack finding at the top rear makes this a good lapel brooch for a jacket or medium-weight fabric.

Shipped fully insured.

name: Brooch: HYMN.  (2013)
description:
Materials: Optometrist's test lens, sea urchin spines, tintype, 18th-century kozo paper, 19th-century paper, text.

A small and eminently wearable brooch with a tie-tack finding at the top rear.

Shipped fully insured.

name: Brooch: HIDDEN LIGHT. (2013)
description:
Materials: 19th-century daguerreotype case, fused glass, 19h-century silk velvet, amythyst, ruby, peridot, 18th-century paper, mother-of-pearl, early 19th-century sterling silver reliquary fragment, brass wire, paper, text, soil.

HIDDEN LIGHT features an image of close friends from an 1840's ambrotype in my collection. This was scanned and fused to clear antique glass, then backed with velvet and jewels to create a radiant memento mori. It is attached to clothing with a single tie-tack finding in back, and is wearable even on lightweight clothing.

Shipped fully insured.

name: Brooch: A Riddle. (2013)
description:
Materials: Victorian wooden spool end, 18th-century brass tacks, fused  glass, beetle specimen, crustacean parts, car tail light fragment, engraving, silver, soil.

3 1/4" (8.2cm) diameter x 1/2" (1.3cm)

An oddity from the start, this brooch offsets the smooth circular geometry with asymmetrical embellishments and an opaque narrative. It attaches to the clothing with two tie-tack backs, and although it is lightweight, would fare best on a sweater or coat due to its circumference.

When backlit, the piece turns red and the mysterious contents are seen in silhouette.

Shipped fully insured.

name: Bracelet: Refuge. (2013)
description:
Materials: Vintage costume bracelet frame, lens, chandelier glass, chandelier crystal from the estate of Ralph Waldo Emerson, amethysts, raw opals, hummingbird feathers, Royal Vienna plate fragments, 19th-century color lithographs, 1850's Stamford, CT ledger paper, fused glass, glass balls, 1850's steel-point engravings, resin, paper, paint, text, soil.

Taking the idea of 'junk jewelry' at its word, I have deconstructed a mid-20th century piece of costume jewelry and treated it as a canvas on which to lay some very sumptuous 'junk' indeed. 

The unknown young woman at the epicenter of the bracelet peers out, tiny cut amethysts rolling in her head, taking refuge in her thoughts. 

She is flanked by a man and woman whose images are fractally diffused behind cast glass 'diamonds.' 

The outer panels have exquisite hand-painted and gilt porcelain from the 1800's, nestled behind cut crystal from the home of the poet Emerson.

The panels together are 6" (15cm) in length, with the addition of 2" (5cm) for the clasp, totalling 8" in length.

Piece will be fully insured.

Several additional detail views can be seen here:
https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.549985661749060.1073741825.100002128939555&type=1&l=085e0b772b

name: Sculptural Object: INJUSTICE IN SMALL THINGS. (2013)
description:
Materials: Antique clock case, chandelier parts, glass, brass casting, 1830's pre-Braille bible page, highly oxidized beetle specimen on plated brass pin, steel and brass wire, waxed linen thread, etched brass, 1860's steel-point engraving, velvet, glass balls, resin, paint, soil.

7.5 x 4 x 3" (19 x 10 x 7.5cm)

A return to form after a year of diversions, INJUSTICE IN SMALL THINGS utilizes an extraordinary insect specimen from the Macleay Museum in Sydney, in which the pin that mounted the beetle oxidized heavily over the 40+ years in a drawer, and the oxidation curiously spread to the specimen itself, creating a shockingly beautiful emerald-green jewel from which the composition radiates. 

The details of the interior are tantalizingly out of reach, as the rippled glass covering prevents a sharp focus, creating a gossamer scrim through which the contents are semi-obscured.

Shipped fully insured.

name: Slim 'Pencil' Automatic Center Punch
description:
Slim 'Pencil' Automatic Center Punch

This is a must-have tool for anyone drilling holes in metal sheet or found objects. Thin design fits easily in the hand and requires less hand strength than the heavier and more common center punches. Pushing down on the tool activates an interior spring and 'pops' a divot into the metal that will make it easy for the drill bit to find its place.  It is adjustable for light to heavy metals.

It's got some other uses as well - it can be used to pattern metals with little pock marks... It's also handy as a scribe to scratch lines in metal and as a nail/screw starter in wood!

These fine punches are more accurate than the heavier models - great for small jewelry work. Complete with a nerdy 'pocket protector' clip so you can wear your new tool proudly and never be seen without it!

name: Diamond Coated Drill Bit / Bur Set
description:
Diamond Coated Drill Bit / Bur Set

20-piece set of diamond-tipped drill bits or burs, to be used in your Dremel or flex-shaft tool at high speeds in a water bath.

For drilling holes in and shaping glass, stone, ceramic and shell.

name: Airring Pair #2.
description:
Pair of mobile earrings, or 'Airrings.'

Left:
3.5 x 3.75" (90 x 95mm)

Right:
3.25 x 4" (83 x 102mm)

Completely one-of-a-kind hand-wrought mobile earrings of Sterling silver, bronze and wood. Earring wires are Sterling silver.

Inspired by Alexander Calder's playful forms and forged from the rustic material and aesthetic of my found-object work, each Airring dances and capers lightly from the ear, creating a dynamic frame for the face that is truly engaging for viewer and wearer alike.

Shipping is fully insured.

name: Keith Lo Bue eFolio Vol. 1 - Expanded & Extended!  - NEW EBOOK
description:
I'm thrilled to introduce my brand-new deluxe 261-page ebook, unveiled after months of preparation!

I've taken my 2006 Folio Edition (seen elsewhere on this site) and redesigned and vastly expanded it - and all optimized for mobile devices! Since it is in the PDF format, it will work beautifully on most e-readers, desktops and devices. Tested and designed for the iPad, where it really shines - but other competitors will view it beautifully, guaranteed.

The original postcard folio chronicles the years from 1989 to 2006. This new eFolio continues all the way up to 2013, while additionally adding dozens of alternate views of all the prior work. Many of the images are taken from my photo archive and are seen here for the first time.

This may just be the lushest art book you can own for your device - with 200 high-resolution images and updated, in-depth text describing the work and its context within the continuum of my creative career.

Upon payment, you'll receive an email with a private link to download your ebook (please allow up to 12 hours for the link to be sent, due to time zone hijinx!).

And here's a special offer: if you buy the eFolio and the Postcard Folio together, you'll get the Postcard folio for only $16.99! That saves $8.00. just enter the discount code: FOLIORAMA at checkout for your discount. (You can find the Folio Edition by clicking on 'BOOKS' in the left-hand menu on this page)

PDF format, full-color, 261p., 170mb file.

name: Neckpiece: A QUESTION OF TASTE.  (2013)
description:
A QUESTION OF TASTE. 2013

Pendant: 5 x 3.5 x 1.5" (13 x 9 x 4cm)

Cord/chain: 31" (78.7cm)

Victorian shirt-stud box, hors d'oeuvres fork, brass, paua shell laminate, lenses, steel engravings, screws, 1790 book cover, antique linen thread, seashell, horseshoe crab spines, crushed markasite, bronze, brass & steel wire, antique keys, silk thread, antique machine drive belt, copper, paper, soil.

The brand-new work from Studio Stuffsmith. Large in dimension but extremely lightweight, A QUESTION OF GRAVITY hangs low on the body. The mobile suspended from the front of the piece is in constant motion with the wearer's movements.

The creation of this piece can be seen step-by-step on my 'Stuffsmith' blog here: 
http://keithlobue.blogspot.com.au/

More images of the piece can be seen on the New Work page of my website here:
http://www.lobue-art.com/new.html

All shipping is fully insured.

name: ebook: STUFFSMITH: The Found-Object Artwork of Keith Lo Bue, Volume One
description:
A fascinating document of the creative process in full swing, Stuffsmith: The Found-Object Artwork of Keith Lo Bue, Volume One is far more then an unabridged transcript of Keith's blog of the same name, from its inception in 2008 to early 2011.

It's studded with high-resolution close-up images of the jewelry and object work completed in those blog posts, and rounded out with several never-before-seen images taken in the artist's Sydney studio.

And it's only $7. 

Upon submitting payment, you will be sent a personal link to download the ebook.

An engrossing and in-depth journey that spans over 350 visually-packed pages, Stuffsmith is a perfect ebook to load on your smartphone or tablet, or simply opened on your desktop for hours of creative enjoyment.

name: Neckpiece: SENTIMENT AND ACTION. (1998)
description:
Neckpiece: SENTIMENT AND ACTION. 1998

Pendant: 4.75 x 2 x 1.4" (12 x 5 x 3.5cm)
Cord: 32" (90cm)
Pendant adjustable along length of cord, bolo tie style

Bannister post fragment, steel wing nuts, king crab legs, copper, Sterling silver, Victorian photo-lithograph, opals, clock key, leather, paper, stainless steel bolo mechanism, soil.

Returned to me after a long stint hidden away and forgotten in a drawer at a gallery, this is a rare opportunity to own one of the last remaining pieces of my late-1990's jewelry.  Sentiment and Action can be adjusted up or down to sit at any point on the chest or neck.

Shipping is fully insured.

name: Neckpiece: MESMERISM.  (2008)
description:
Victorian spoon and forks, brass, bronze artifact, raw opal, waxed linen thread, steel wire, leather, soil.

Pendant: 5" circumference (12cm)
1.5" deep (4cm)
Chain/cord: 34" (86cm)

MESMERISM is constructed of multiple pieces of Victorian cutlery, splayed like stretched fingers into a ceremonial radius. The energy generated by this design is softened by the use of linen thread, which does the double duty of seeming to harness  the spread of the fork tines, while gently containing the beating heart of the piece: a massive shard of raw opal.

This piece is the first to utilize my new chain design, based on an archaic chain belt drive, which I have affectionately dubbed 'The Eskridge', for the kind soul who allowed me to study her fragment of early nineteenth-century machinery. Thank you, Janet.

All shipping is fully insured.

name: Large Round-Nose Pliers
description:
Large 7" Round-Nose Pliers

For years - yes, years - I've been threatening to source these to sell to workshop participants. They are just incredibly hard to find, no matter on which side of the earth you reside.

Easy and comfortable in the hand, these babies offer plenty of grunt to manipulate larger or harder wire than your small jewelry round-nose pliers can handle.

This means that for steel, brass, nickel, bronze and even heavy gauge copper or silver, they simply can't be beat. Additionally, the round jaws taper up to a larger size than smaller round-nose pliers, too - so larger loops and curves can be made.

All of which is to say, if you work with wire, and/or you have taken or are even thinking of taking a workshop with Yours Truly,
you owe it to Yourself to have these in your toolbox!

name: DVD Workshop: TOOLS OF THE TRADE: Essential Tools for Artists
description:
TOOLS OF THE TRADE: Essential Tools for Artists

Available on DVD at long last! The first workshop ever offered in video format by renowned found-object artist Keith Lo Bue, TOOLS OF THE TRADE: Essential Tools for Artists will give you practical, detailed and intimate demonstrations of drilling, shaping and finishing a whole host of materials used for art-making, including metal, wood, plastic, mica, bone, stone, glass, ceramic and shell, safely and efficiently.

Learn in plain and easy-to-follow detail the proper tool to use for each material. In addition, the amazing jewelers saw will also be explored, with careful instruction on how to work with it and understand its basics.

DVD Features Include:

• Five in-depth lessons covering:  Comprehensive Drilling through multiple materials  (2 lessons)  /  The Cut-Off Wheel  /   The Jewelers Saw demystified  / Lo Bue’s tool recommendations

• On Tools and Inspiration:  An affectionate journey through Keith’s workshop as he discusses his  favorite tools and reflects on the special role tools play in his creative life and art.

• Bonus Film Previews:  Trailers for Lo Bue’s other acclaimed films about creativity and art

“Filmed in my studio in Sydney, you’ll feel like you’re sitting in a chair at my side as we thoroughly explore the world of the most crucial tools for makers of small objects, assemblage and mixed-media jewelry.
 
“Whether you’re a beginner in creative exploration, or an old hand looking to get some great new insights into your tools, this workshop is packed with great tips, information – and many of my own low-tech variations on traditional methods  – that will enhance your own creative path.”   – Keith Lo Bue

So join Keith for the workshop that’s been called “the key to unlocking creativity” (P. Haddock) - and unlock your own!

Video preview can be seen here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qq1GsOeyLzE

188 minutes on two DVD-R's

name: Stuffsmith Portable Jump-Ring Jig
description:
Jump-ringing never felt this good before! Made lovingly by hand by Yours Truly, this jig will not only enable you to power through jump rings of any metal (including steel) at a greatly accelerated speed, it will help you saw links of unusual shape or dimensions with ease.

I cut thousands of jump-rings - this is field-tested and stuffsmith-approved!

Check out this link to see The Stuffsmith Portable Jump-Ring Jig in action. It's a silent excerpt from my worldwide online workshop entitled "STEELING BEAUTY: Chains, Clasps & Forms in Steel Wire", starting in June of this year.

http://youtu.be/yrSHafLpu1A

Come to think of it, why don't you join me for the online class? You can find information about it here:  http://artful gathering.com

Kiss fumbling with your ring clamp goodbye and start doing the jump-ring jig! Comes with jig, leather hanging strap and coil wedge/chock (clamps not included). Check stock below, and if sold out, send me a message and I'll whip one up for you!

name: Neckpiece: A QUESTION OF GRAVITY.  (2004)
description:
Spoons, chandelier crystal, indigo-dyed twine, pyrite, steel, 16th-century paper, leather, scissor handle, porcelain dentists' teeth, steel-point engraving, brass, paper, text, soil.

Pendant: 4.5" x 2.5" x 1.5" (11.4 x 6.3 x 3.8cm) 
Cord length: 31" (78.7cm) 

GRAVITY came about when I found three spoons in a goodwill 
that were so worn from use that I was astonished; 
they were pitted and eroded at the ends dramatically. 
I held the three together to create a niche and the piece was 
off and running. I mounted the teeth as a dentist would in a mouth,
by creating metal posts that insert into the porcelain, to be cemented in place. 

The twine was indigo-dyed by my good friend Adele Outteridge in Brisbane.

All shipping is fully insured.

name: DVD: Why the Wind Blows, and Other Popular Delusions
description:
This DVD chronicles the first large-scale exhibition of Lo Bue's work in Australia. Assembled here is a survey of twenty years of working 
with found materials, encompassing jewelry, objects and eyewear. Many pieces are from the artist's own collection that have never before been exhibited. 

Also displayed are several rarely-seen collaborative works with a range of distinguished artists: jewelers Robert Ebendorf and Marcia Macdonald, book artist Daniel Essig, paper artist & poet 
Betty Oliver, embroiderer Jane Nicholas, glassblower Sally Prasch 
and basketry pioneer Dorothy Gill Barnes. 

The exhibition took place at Hervey Bay Regional Gallery on the beautiful Fraser Coast in Queensland in July 2010.

An atmospheric video takes you through the expansive space, showing intimate details of the work. This is followed by two talks presented during the opening: a thirty-minute address given by the artist on the gallery floor, and the official opening of the exhibition presented by internationally renowned Australian book artist Adele Outteridge.

Included in the booklet is a powerful and poetic essay written by pre-eminent Sydney sculptor Michael Buzacott.

Film trailer can be viewed here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SpnZbZF5Wdw

56 minutes
DVD-R in slimline case

name: Steel Wire - 20 gauge (.8mm)
description:
20 gauge (.8mm) dark annealed steel wire

As maddeningly elusive in some areas as it is easy to find in others (in fact, this is the only place you're likely to find it in this gauge in Australia), this is the magic stuff I'm always crowing about...

Non-galvanized, dead-soft steel wire that is a wonder to work with. Chains, forms, mechanisms, structures - all brilliant uses for this industrial wire. 

Spool is approx. 8m' (26ft)

name: Miniature Archimedes "Pin" Drill
description:
Designed thousands of years ago, this tiny Archimedes drill uses tiny jeweler's drill bits (#61-80) to put incredibly small holes in metal, wood, plastic, bone, bookboard, leather, mica and a million other materials. Perfect if you are sewing an object onto fabric, or wiring it into place in an assemblage. Now you can make the hole perfectly sized to the connecting material - no more giant holes all over your artwork.

I've had my pin drills manufactured without the annoying spring that is commonly found on this tool. Without the spring, the drill is gentle and responsive, allowing holes to be drilled in fragile or delicate materials (eggshell, anyone?), as well as heavy items like coins, etc.

Copy and paste the YouTube link below into your browser to see the pin drill in action. It's a silent excerpt from my TOOLS OF THE TRADE: Essential Tools for Artists DVD Workshop, also available from this site.

http://youtu.be/fr0m7U5wAGI

Look on this site for the 'Miniature Drill Bits' that are used with this tool.

name: Miniature Drill Bits
description:
Miniature (sizes 61-80) Drill Bits in Steel Index Case

Although jewelry supply stores have these mini size (#61-80) drill bits, it's rare to find them in these cool mini steel index cases that mimic
their full-size cousins, which is why I make sure I have these on hand for sale to use with the amazing Archimedes pin drill.

These micro-bits allow you to make perfect pinholes in metal, wood, bookboard, plastic, mica, paper and much more!

name: Sculptural Object: Spoonfed - A Doll  (2008)
description:
Materials: Georgian spoons, Victorian forks, black bean pods, steel wool, doll eyes, steel brads, steel wire, Victorian hairbrush, eucalyptus seed pod, gelatin mold, paper, epoxy resin, soil.

Gazing upward with a rather tragic-comic expression of pathos, Spoonfed was the offspring of an invitation to create a doll for a book by Linda & Opie O'Brien entitled, "Who's Your Dada?"

Not being one to forego a challenge, I sat in my studio puzzling over what a doll meant to me in context of my concerns with found materials. 

My own experience of dolls tends to bring me back to my pre-teen years, to those jointed superheroes that filled my days with private adventure. But the single doll that dominates my memory is the two foot tall Dr. Doolittle that spoke when a cord was pulled in his hip.  I played with him until he was in pieces, then kept playing with his disembodied head for a few years more.

Since so much about the personal meaning of a doll is generated by a sense of character, I simply began with a face. Taking a wonderful spoon from the early 1800's and cutting features into its surface, the gruff but inquisitive little Spoonfed emerged and demanded the appropriate body. And some soup.

As a table object, he will be better placed rather low, so the viewer towers over him, giving his questioning stare added humor. His dripping spoon hovers over a soup bowl, as if he is pausing for permission to, as it were, eat his words.

name: Pair of Handmade Mobile Balance Wands
description:
Pair of Handmade Mobile Balance Wands

With handles individually hand-turned in beautiful Tasmanian oak, these two wands will rarely be out of your hands while creating a mobile or stabile construction. I've developed these for my own use, so I can enthusiastically endorse their usefulness! Small and large sizes will enable you to work with the tiniest forms right up to heavy weight structures.

Note: As these are totally handmade tools, design may vary slightly from those in picture.

name: Deluxe Poetry Package - A Kit for Poetry in Motion Workshop
description:
While this kit doesn't have it all, it compiles some of the most important class tools/materials for the mobiles class at a discount. This package is perfect for those who have not taken classes with me before, and/or need the pliers and cutters on the supply list.

Deluxe Poetry Package:

Contains:
One Set - Swivels - mini set of 10
One Set - 4-Piece Balance Finder set
One Set - 2 Piece Balance Wands S/L
One Set - Hand-Cut Wooden Shapes 
Two - 1mm drill bits
Two - .9mm drill bits
Two - .8mm drill bits
One - Memory Wire Cutter
One - Large Round-Nose Plier
One - Mini Linesman Plier

name: 4-Piece Mobile Balance-Finder Set
description:
4-Piece Mobile Balance-Finder Set

This is a special set of four tweezers that I have hand-modified for use in finding the balance points in mobile making. Each one works perfectly for different objects or material situations.

Chromed metal.

name: Poetry Package - A Kit for Poetry in Motion Workshop
description:
While this kit doesn't have it all, it compiles some of the most important class tools/materials for the mobiles class at a discount. This package is perfect for those who have taken classes with me before, and may have some of the pliers, etc. already. 

Those who want the large round nose pliers, memory wire cutters & mini linesman pliers to go with this set, go for the Deluxe Poetry Package: http://www.keithlobue.com/product/deluxe-poetry-package-a-kit-for-poetry-in-motion-workshop

Poetry Package: $74:

Contains:
One Set - Swivels - mini set of 10
One Set - 4-Piece Balance Finder set
One Set - 2 Piece Balance Wands S/L
One Set - Hand-Cut Wooden Shapes 
Two - 1mm drill bits
Two - .9mm drill bits
Two - .8mm drill bits

name: 18-20 Gauge Drill Bit Trio
description:
1mm Drill Bit (matches 18 gauge wire)
.9mm Drill Bit (matches 19 gauge wire)
.8mm Drill Bit (matches 20 gauge wire)

They will allow holes to be drilled into metal, wood, plastic and bone for use in making mobiles, assembling with found objects and so much more.

These bits will not be used in a standard power drill due to their tiny size, but in a miniature hand drill such as the brass archimedes drill in this store, or in a flexible-shaft tool.

Price includes one of each of the three sizes of drill bit.

name: Set of 10 Mini Mobile Swivels
description:
Two each of five tiny swivels suitable for small to large-sized mobiles and stabiles. Blackened nickel finish. Paintable. 

These are the best swivels I've found for mobile construction. The largest swivels here will support up to 48lbs (22kg) of weight!

name: Hand-Cut Wooden Shapes for Mobiles
description:
Hand-Cut Wooden Shapes for Mobiles

Here's a pack of 17 hand-cut shapes for use in mobile-making. Four each of three sizes of round disc and one of square segments, finished off with a 19x19mm cube.

Note: As pictured, you can see these are raw wood, and are unfinished. A few rubs with a light sandpaper will clean these up, ready to be painted or varnished in a mobile structure. Square shapes are pine, round shapes are Tasmanian oak.

name: Galvanized Steel Wire - 22 gauge (.7mm)
description:
22 gauge (.7mm) galvanized steel wire

Ultra-fine gauge of wire that's excellent for making the thinnest elements of small-scale mobiles. Galvanized coating prohibits rusting, so can be used indoor and outdoor. Readily paint-able and easy to manipulate. Can be used for mobile jewelry when painted.

Approx. 50ft/15 metres

name: Galvanized Steel Wire - 20 gauge (.8mm)
description:
Galvanized Steel Wire - 20 gauge (.8mm)

Fine gauge of wire that's excellent for making mobiles. Galvanized coating prohibits rusting, so can be used for indoor and outdoor structures. Readily paint-able and easy to manipulate. Can be used for mobile jewelry when painted.

Approx. 50ft/15 metres

name: Galvanized Steel Wire - 18 gauge (1mm)
description:
Medium gauge of wire that's excellent for making mobiles. Galvanized coating prohibits rusting, so can be used for indoor and outdoor structures. Readily paint-able and easy to manipulate. Can be used for mobile jewelry when painted.

Approx. 25ft/7.6 metres

name: Galvanized Steel Wire - 16 gauge (1.57mm)
description:
Medium/heavy gauge of wire that's excellent for making mobiles. Galvanized coating prohibits rusting, so can be used for indoor and outdoor structures. Readily paint-able and easy to manipulate. Can be used for mobile jewelry when painted.

Coil shown as pictured.

name: Sanding Sponge Block - Course/Fine
description:
Sanding Sponge Block - Course/Fine

Excellent tool for smoothing edges of cut metal shapes in mobile-making, sanding wooden parts, and adding textural 'tooth' to metal in preparation for priming/painting.

name: DVD: Within and Without: A work in 6 episodes
description:
Within and Without (a work in 6 episodes) offers us that rarest of opportunities: to accompany an artist on a journey into the creative process. 

Join noted American art jeweler Keith 
Lo Bue in his studio in Sydney, Australia as he spontaneously fashions an intricate neckpiece made of very unexpected and unusual materials.  Described as 'museums of dreams' by one critic, 
Lo Bue's artwork conjures a world in which the Brothers Quay might sit in Joseph Cornell's lap reading Jules Verne.

Framed as an imaginary play in six parts, Within and Without treats the tiny wearable sculpture as a developing narrative; each component part adds another piece to the evolving puzzle, and we watch with the artist as that 'plot' takes form chapter by chapter over the course of a week.  In Lo Bue's miniature realm the commonplace becomes the extraordinary as a ragtag cast of typewriter parts, accordion keys, chandelier crystals, centuries-old books and much more are transformed into a final object of wonder and beauty.  The film is suffused throughout with a mesmerizing score by New York's celebrated avant-garde composer Guy Klucevsek.

Anyone with an interest in how things are made will find themselves drawn into the maze of surprises, setbacks and solutions that lead to the finished artwork.  

Completely unrehearsed, unscripted and documented in close-up detail, Within and Without is an intimate portrait of discovery and delight in the possibilities of the physical world, wedded with the limitless potential of the imagination!

Film trailer can be viewed here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUTXsBlXTPI

39 minutes

Note for North American Orders: North American orders of this DVD are not eligible for a multi-item shipping discount, as it ships separately to other items.

name: Miniature Linesman's Pliers
description:
After my large round-nose pliers, this miniature version of the ubiquitous linesman's plier gets the most use in my studio!

Able to grip steel, brass, nickel and bronze wire securely to squeeze, crimp and otherwise manipulate it to your bidding. All the while they are light and ergonomic in the hand. I use two, end-to-end, to open and close jump rings.

I hand-grind each plier to remove the sharpness on the edges that can nick wire as it's being manipulated.

These little pliers couldn't come more highly recommended, and this new top-quality design is the best I've ever offered for sale.

name: Glue Syringe with Cap (empty)
description:
This 30cc (30ml/1oz.) syringe is the one I've crowed about for decades in my workshops, and until now has been very hard to source.
Although you can use it for any adhesive you prefer, I have long advocated it to hold the water-based caulking/sealant that I recommend as an adhesive and so much more in my found-object workshops.

The tiny tip makes it an excellent applicator to apply small amounts in tight spaces. What makes it so great is that the snap-down cap ensures that you can store the sealant inside for years without it drying out (as long as you always replace the cap right after use!).

In the US, the brand of caulking I recommend ('DAP Kwik-Seal') comes in a large squeezeable tube, which can decant easily into this syringe
and then top-up as necessary.

Those in Australia have a harder time of finding the equivalent stuff - the only one sold in AU is 'Fuller Ultra-Clear', and it only comes in a
full-size caulking-gun tube, so it simply must be decanted into a syringe for use in artwork. And sadly, it seems to be getting harder to find, as Selley's pushes into more stores. So if you are outside the US and you're having trouble finding Fuller Ultra-Clear, you may choose to order a syringe that I've pre-filled with Fuller Ultra-Clear (found on this site).

name: Perfect Wire Brush
description: A no-fuss, good quality brass-plated steel bristle soft brush that has the perfect hardness and spacing of bristle to clean and polish the steel wire I work with as well as scores of other metals. (Note: not for use on silver or gold)

name: Book: Keith Lo Bue's Folio Edition, Volume 1: Jewelry
description:
Selected from the works of Keith Lo Bue and formed into a folio edition.

The set documents work from each year of making from 1989 to 2006 in 24 full-color plates. Lavishly packaged in a sleek matte-black embossed folio case. Measuring 8.25 x 6" (21 x 15cm), each plate has a postcard back listing information about the work.

Rounding out the publication is an eight-page booklet of notes and anecdotes about the selected pieces, providing a rich context and perspective on the artist's creative methods and thought processes.

The Folio Edition is equally at home on your shelf of art books, for giving as a gift, or for sending individually as large postcards.

"This collection consists of jewelry I considered then, as now, to be some of the best examples from each year at the bench. One may see in their chronology the seeds of coming changes in technique, material and subject matter." - KL

And now for the great news - this box set, normally $50, is now available for only $24.99 (plus shipping & handling)!

A video teaser showing the folio and all 24 plates can be viewed here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k8sNvi11zcc

name: Steel Wire - 16 gauge (1.57mm)
description:
16 gauge (1.57mm) dark annealed steel wire

As maddeningly elusive in some areas as it is easy to find in others, this is the magic stuff that I've been teaching others to use for the past two decades! 

Non-galvanized, dead-soft steel wire that is a wonder to work with. Chains, forms, mechanisms, structures - all brilliant uses for this industrial wire. Its strength is more than matched by its beauty!

Spool is approx. 400grams in weight (for cheaper shipping)

NOTE: This size wire is sold on the site mainly for those in AUSTRALIA/NEW ZEALAND who have problems sourcing it. In the US, this 're-bar wire' is found in almost every hardware store and should be purchased there. The heavy weight would make shipping to the US extremely expensive and unnecessary.

name: Extra-Wide Bench Pin
description:
Here's a simple, clean pine extra-wide bench pin I make carefully by hand for use with your jeweler's saw or for bracing things
against on your bench front. Just clamp with any G-clamp or bar clamp and you have a super wide surface that will accommodate larger
objects to saw, file or alter. 

Most jewelry-store bench pins lack a wide enough 'V' to allow a ring clamp or gripping plier to fit inside, which is why I offer them here. This wide opening allows you to hold a ring clamp or plier firmly in the 'V' for cutting jump-rings, sanding, shaping or filing. Tiny 'V' cuts in the tips allow wire to be held still for filing or shaping. 

Smooth, grooved and stuffsmith-approved!

name: Super-Fine Polishing Papers
description:
3M Micron Polishing Paper Kit

Notoriously unpredictable to find outside the US, especially in this full size, here are the polishing papers any self-respecting stuffsmith can't
live without. 

Rendering buffing machines moot, these micro-fine papers will allow you to hand-polish metal, wood, plastic, shell and a host of
other materials to a chromium gleam.

name: Reinforced cut-off wheel
description:
Reinforced Cut-Off Wheel for rotary tools like Dremel. Bosch, etc.

At a fraction of the price of the brand-name rotary tool accessories, these fibreglass-reinforced wheels can grind, sand and cut through the toughest materials like butter.

For rotary tool use on metal (even hardened steel!), wood, plastic, and much more. Fits standard 1/8" rotary-tool screw-top mandrels (not included).

Learn in detail how to use these wheels in my DVD Workshop called "Tools of the Trade: Essential Tools for Artists."

name: DVD: The Maculate Conception from The Impermanent Collection
description:
DVD film: The Maculate Conception from The Impermanent Collection - Keith Lo Bue: Work & Influence

A thought-provoking and hypnotic tour through Lo Bue's work, The Maculate Conception from The Impermanent Collection delves into the curious imagery and memories of childhood wonder that would forge Lo Bue's world view and aesthetic direction.

Originally presented as a keynote presentation to the Jewellers and Metalsmiths' Group of Australia (JMGA).

Newly expanded and visually enhanced, with a soundtrack composed and performed by Lo Bue himself. Many of the artworks shown have never been seen in any other form.

Film trailer can be viewed here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WMFVAu3oWOw

23 minutes
DVD-R in Slimline CD Case

name: Neckpiece: TWO SIDES OF HISTORY.  (2009)
description:
Steel animal trap, steel wire, drawer-pull, copper, nickel silver, brass, glass, upholstery tacks, pearls, antique steel keys, steel bolt, optometrist test lens, seaweed root-ball fragment, 18th-century French map, vintage earnuts, steel-point engraving (1850's), linen thread, leather, paint, soil.

Pendant: 6.75" x 3.75" x .75" 
(17 x 9.5 x 2.5cm)
Cord length around neck: 19" (48.2cm)
Vertical drop of cord, from top center loop to pendant: 7.5" (19cm)

The latest in my ongoing series of disarmed and radically reconfigured animal traps. Two Sides of History is notable for the fact that is the first of my pieces to prominently feature objects that have been altered and fused with glass. 

The piece hangs in a singular way: the cord/s circles the neck quite closely, like a small chain might be worn; the pendant then dangles, pendulum-like, straight down from there to the belly. Because of the open structure, this neckpiece is not heavy like it appears and is quite comfortable to wear.

The creation of Two Sides of History has been chronicled 
in detail on my blog here:

Part 1: http://keithlobue.blogspot.com.au/2009/07/two-sides-of-history-in-progress-pt1.html

Part 2: http://keithlobue.blogspot.com.au/2009/07/two-sides-of-history-pt-2.html


All shipping is fully insured.

name: Brooch: untitled (watch case)  (2011)
description:
Wristwatch case, brass nail, Czech crystal, 19th-century lithograph, glass balls, resin.

All shipping is fully insured.

name: Memory Wire Cutters  (Hardened Wire Shears)
description:
Memory Wire Cutters  (Hardened Wire Shears)

The smart choice for cutting steel wire - easy on the hands and creating flush ends on wire. These workhorses will make quick work of cutting multiple lengths (essential for making chains), or just for snipping off of the roll. They'll even cut through hardened steel spring-wire with no harm to the blades!

name: Steel Wire - 18 gauge (1.25mm)
description:
18 gauge (1.25mm) dark annealed steel wire

As maddeningly elusive in some areas as it is easy to find in others (in fact, this is the only place you're likely to find it in this gauge in Australia), this is the magic stuff I'm always crowing about... 

Non-galvanized, dead-soft steel wire that is a wonder to work with. Chains, forms, mechanisms, structures - all brilliant uses for this industrial wire. 

Spool is approx. 8m' (26ft)

name: Steel Wire - 19 gauge (.9mm)
description:
19 gauge (.9mm) dark annealed steel wire

As maddeningly elusive in some areas as it is easy to find in others, this is the magic stuff I'm always crowing about...

Non-galvanized, dead-soft steel wire that is a wonder to work with. Chains, forms, mechanisms, structures - all brilliant uses for this industrial wire. 

Spool is approx. 8m' (26ft)

name: Glue Syringe with Cap (filled)
description:
This is the glue-filled syringe described below, especially for those Down Unda that have trouble finding the glue...

This 30cc (30ml/1oz.) syringe is the one I've crowed about for decades in my workshops, and until now has been very hard to source.
Although you can use it for any adhesive you prefer, I have long advocated it to hold the water-based caulking/sealant that I recommend as an adhesive and so much more in my found-object workshops.

The tiny tip makes it an excellent applicator to apply small amounts in tight spaces. What makes it so great is that the snap-down cap ensures that you can store the sealant inside for years without it drying out (as long as you always replace the cap right after use!).

In the US, the brand of caulking I recommend ('DAP Kwik-Seal') comes in a large squeezeable tube, which can decant easily into this syringe
and then top-up as necessary. The empty syringe can be found for sale on this site.

Those in Australia have a harder time of finding the equivalent glue - the only one sold in AU is 'Fuller Ultra-Clear', and it only comes in a
full-size caulking-gun tube, so it simply must be decanted into a syringe for use in artwork. And sadly, it seems to be getting harder to find, as Selley's pushes into more stores.
